elements.content: Recrystallization of enantiopure amino acid derivatives N-(2-pyridylmethyl)-alanine in MeOH resulted in high quality crystals of compounds 1 (l-Hpala) and 2 (d-Hpala). Self-assembly of l- or d-Hpala with Zn(CH3CO2)2·2H2O in MeOH in a ratio of 2:1 produced two enantiopure neutral mononuclear complexes [Zn(l-pala)2]·H2O (3) and [Zn(d-pala)2]·H2O (4) with almost quantitative yields. X-ray single crystal diffraction analyses reveal that they are two-dimensional undulate homochiral supramolecular structures. Circular dichroism (CD) spectra confirm that 1 and 2, 3 and 4 are one pair of enantiomers, respectively. [Cu1.5(spp)(bpy)1.5(H2O)2(NO3)](NO3)·4H2O (5) was prepared by the self-assembly of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O, pala−, and 4.4′-dipyridyl (bpy) in a H2O−EtOH mixture involving the in situ formation of a Schiff base ligand N-(2-pyridylmethyl)-pyruvic acid (spp−). Compound 5 crystallized in the centrosymmetric C2/c space group. It features a three-dimensional supramolecular network by interconnection of an antenna-shaped Cu-containing sheet and a hydrogen bonded supramolecular layer in the alternate ...ABAB... stacking mode. The solid-state photoluminescence properties of 1 and 3 were also investigated.

elements.content: Five supramolecular structures constructed from N-(2-pyridylmethyl)-alanine (Hpala) and its in situ oxidized derivative N-(2-pyridylmethyl)-pyruvic acid (Hspp) were synthesized and structurally characterized. Their chiroptical and photoluminescence properties were also investigated.

Their chiroptical and photoluminescence properties were also investigated.

elements.content: The realm of crystal engineering has gone beyond a variety of disciplines. Crystal engineering approaches including the use of coordination bond, hydrogen bond, π−π stacking, and other intermolecular interactions have been widely used in preparation of materials with interesting structures and properties. Among them the hydrogen bond is one of the most attractive methods as it is relatively strong and directionally specific. As exhibited in the advanced structures of proteins, amino acids and its peptide derivatives are naturally potential candidates for hydrogen-bonded supramolecular networks because the amino groups and carboxylate groups of amino acids are excellent hydrogen bond donors and acceptors. More importantly, most of the natural amino acids are optically active, which plays a key role in the chiral recognition process in biological systems. The modifiability of the amino groups of amino acids has been widely explored by chemists, which further developed their potential in synthesizing homochiral supramolecular materials. Schiff base and reduced Schiff base generated by the condensation of amino acids and salicylaldehyde or pyridinecarboxaldehyde are one of the mostly used ligands of this kind. Some progress has been made in one-dimensional (1D) water helix, molecular capsule, cation recognition, thermal induced solid-state conversion between two different networks, solvent and coordination sphere influenced conformation diversity, and temperature-dependent conformation diversity. Among them the compound featuring 1D water helix encapsulated in a 1D helical coordination polymer [(H2O)2@{Ni(Hsglu)(H2O)2}]·H2O (H3sglu = N-(2-hydroxybenzyl)-l-glutamic acid) is one of the most interesting examples of homochiral supramolecular networks. More recently, two homochiral enantiomeric single-helical structures [Cu(l-pasp)(H2O)]·4H2O and [Cu(d-pasp)(H2O)]·4H2O (Hpasp = N-(2-pyridylmethyl)-aspartic acid) have been reported. It should be noted that the intrinsic chirality of the amino acids that originated from the α-C atom has always been introduced into the crystal structures. The above examples convincingly suggest that amino acid derivatives are excellent candidates for constructing homochiral supramolecular structures. Herein, we report five supramolecular compounds: N-(2-pyridylmethyl)-l-alanine (l-Hpala) (1), N-(2-pyridylmethyl)-d-alanine (d-Hpala) (2), [Zn(l-pala)2]·H2O (3), [Zn(d-pala)2]·H2O (4), and [Cu1.5(spp)(bpy)1.5(H2O)2(NO3)](NO3)·4H2O (5) (Hspp = N-(2-pyridylmethyl)-pyruvic acid), concerning their syntheses, structures, chiroptical, and photoluminescence properties.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The realm of crystal engineering has gone beyond a variety of disciplines. Crystal engineering approaches including the use of coordination bond, hydrogen bond, π-π stacking, and other intermolecular interactions have been widely used in preparation of materials with interesting structures and properties. Among them the hydrogen bond is one of the most attractive methods as it is relatively strong and directionally specific. As exhibited in the advanced structures of proteins, amino acids and its peptide derivatives are naturally potential candidates for hydrogen-bonded supramolecular networks because the amino groups and carboxylate groups of amino acids are excellent hydrogen bond donors and acceptors. More importantly, most of the natural amino acids are optically active, which plays a key role in the chiral recognition process in biological systems. The modifiability of the amino groups of amino acids has been widely explored by chemists, which further developed their potential in synthesizing homochiral supramolecular materials. Schiff base and reduced Schiff base generated by the condensation of amino acids and salicylaldehyde or pyridinecarboxaldehyde are one of the mostly used ligands of this kind. Some progress has been made in one-dimensional (1D) water helix, molecular capsule, cation recognition, thermal induced solid-state conversion between two different networks, solvent and coordination sphere influenced conformation diversity, and temperature-dependent conformation diversity. Among them the compound featuring 1D water helix encapsulated in a 1D helical coordination polymer [(H2O)2@{Ni(Hsglu)(H2O)2}]⋅H2O (H3sglu = N-(2-hydroxybenzyl)-l-glutamic acid) is one of the most interesting examples of homochiral supramolecular networks. More recently, two homochiral enantiomeric single-helical structures [Cu(l-pasp)(H2O)]⋅4H2O and [Cu(d-pasp)(H2O)]⋅4H2O (Hpasp = N-(2-pyridylmethyl)-aspartic acid) have been reported. It should be noted that the intrinsic chirality of the amino acids that originated from the α-C atom has always been introduced into the crystal structures. The above examples convincingly suggest that amino acid derivatives are excellent candidates for constructing homochiral supramolecular structures. Herein, we report five supramolecular compounds: N-(2-pyridylmethyl)-l-alanine (l-Hpala) (1), N-(2-pyridylmethyl)-d-alanine (d-Hpala) (2), [Zn(l-pala)2]⋅H2O (3), [Zn(d-pala)2]⋅H2O (4), and [Cu1.5(spp)(bpy)1.5(H2O)2(NO3)](NO3)⋅4H2O (5) (Hspp = N-(2-pyridylmethyl)-pyruvic acid), concerning their syntheses, structures, chiroptical, and photoluminescence properties.

elements.content: All chemicals used for the synthesis were obtained from commercial sources and were used without further purification. Organic solvents used in this paper were of analytical purity. All reactions were carried out at atmospheric conditions. N-(2-Pyridylmethyl)-l-alanine ligand was synthesized by a literature method. Elemental analyses of C, H, and N were determined using a Vario MICRO E III elemental analyzer. The 1H NMR spectra of Hpala ligands were recorded on a Varian Unity 500FT-NMR spectrometer at room temperature in D2O. Infrared (IR) spectra were recorded on PerkinElmer Spectrum One instrument as KBr pellets in the range of 4000−400 cm−1. Thermogravimetric analyses were performed on an NETZSCH STA 449C unit at a heating rate of 10 °C/min under nitrogen atmosphere. Solid-state photoluminescent spectra of compounds 1 and 3 were measured at room temperature with an Edinburgh FLS920 fluorescence spectrometer. The instrument is equipped with an Edinburgh Xe900 xenon arc lamp as the exciting light source. Solid-state circular dichroism (CD) spectra of compounds 1−4 were recorded using a JASCO J-810 spectrometer. For each CD measurement ca. 0.5 mg crystalline sample was taken to be mixed with 45 mg of dried and well ground KCl powder. This mixture was then pressed into a disk by a literature method. Specific rotation of compounds 1 and 2 were measured on a WZZ-1S auto-optical rotation instrument using a sodium source radiation (589.4 nm, D) at 20 °C (0.1 g·mL−1, dissolved in distilled water).
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and General Methods

All chemicals used for the synthesis were obtained from commercial sources and were used without further purification. Organic solvents used in this paper were of analytical purity. All reactions were carried out at atmospheric conditions. N-(2-Pyridylmethyl)-l-alanine ligand was synthesized by a literature method. Elemental analyses of C, H, and N were determined using a Vario MICRO E III elemental analyzer. The 1H NMR spectra of Hpala ligands were recorded on a Varian Unity 500FT-NMR spectrometer at room temperature in D2O. Infrared (IR) spectra were recorded on PerkinElmer Spectrum One instrument as KBr pellets in the range of 4000-400 cm-1. Thermogravimetric analyses were performed on an NETZSCH STA 449C unit at a heating rate of 10 °C/min under nitrogen atmosphere. Solid-state photoluminescent spectra of compounds 1 and 3 were measured at room temperature with an Edinburgh FLS920 fluorescence spectrometer. The instrument is equipped with an Edinburgh Xe900 xenon arc lamp as the exciting light source. Solid-state circular dichroism (CD) spectra of compounds 1-4 were recorded using a JASCO J-810 spectrometer. For each CD measurement ca. 0.5 mg crystalline sample was taken to be mixed with 45 mg of dried and well ground KCl powder. This mixture was then pressed into a disk by a literature method. Specific rotation of compounds 1 and 2 were measured on a WZZ-1S auto-optical rotation instrument using a sodium source radiation (589.4 nm, D) at 20 °C (0.1 g⋅mL-1, dissolved in distilled water).

elements.content: As described in the literature, l-Hpala (or d-Hpala) was synthesized by the condensation reaction of 2-pyridinecarboxaldehyde with alanine (l- for 1 and d- for 2) and subsequent reduction by NaBH4. X-ray quality single crystals and analytically pure samples were obtained by recrystallization in MeOH. Calculated for C9H12N2O2: C, 59.99; H, 6.71; N, 15.55%. Found: C, 59.58, H, 6.58; N, 15.17%. 1H NMR in D2O (ppm), 1.541 (3H, d), 3.781 (1H, q), 4.377 (2H, s), 7.475 (1H, t), 7.522 (1H, d), 7.914 (1H, t), 8.586 (1H, d). [α]20 D = +5.2° for l-Hpala (dextrorotatory); [α]20 D = −5.2° for d-Hpala (levorotatory).

Syntheses of l-Hpala (1) and d-Hpala (2)

As described in the literature, l-Hpala (or d-Hpala) was synthesized by the condensation reaction of 2-pyridinecarboxaldehyde with alanine (l- for 1 and d- for 2) and subsequent reduction by NaBH4. X-ray quality single crystals and analytically pure samples were obtained by recrystallization in MeOH. Calculated for C9H12N2O2: C, 59.99; H, 6.71; N, 15.55%. Found: C, 59.58, H, 6.58; N, 15.17%. 1H NMR in D2O (ppm), 1.541 (3H, d), 3.781 (1H, q), 4.377 (2H, s), 7.475 (1H, t), 7.522 (1H, d), 7.914 (1H, t), 8.586 (1H, d). IR (KBr, cm-1): v =C-H, 3028 (m); v CH3, 2979 (m); v CH2, 2841 (m); v NH2 +, 2250-2700 (m, br); v as(CO2 -),1578 (vs); v s(CO2 -), 1397 (vs). [α]20 D = +5.2° for l-Hpala (dextrorotatory); [α]20 D = -5.2° for d-Hpala (levorotatory).

elements.content: Zn(CH3CO2)2·2H2O (1 mmol) and Hpala (l- for 3 and d- for 4) (2 mmol) were dissolved in MeOH (10 mL) and stirred for 30 min. The clear solution thus formed was left undisturbed for slow evaporation. Colorless rodlike crystals were harvested several days later, washed with a small amount of EtOH, and then with ethyl ether, air-dried. Yield: 92%. Calculated for C18H24N4O5Zn: C, 48.94; H, 5.48; N, 12.68%. Found: C, 48.77, H, 5.54; N, 12.37%. IR (KBr, cm−1): v OH, vNH, 3420 (s, br); v =C−H, 3208 (s); v CH3, 2918 (w); v as(CO2 −), 1617 (vs); v s(CO2 −), 1388 (s).

Syntheses of [Zn(l-pala)2]⋅H2O (3) and [Zn(d-pala)2]⋅H2O (4)

Zn(CH3CO2)2⋅2H2O (1 mmol) and Hpala (l- for 3 and d- for 4) (2 mmol) were dissolved in MeOH (10 mL) and stirred for 30 min. The clear solution thus formed was left undisturbed for slow evaporation. Colorless rodlike crystals were harvested several days later, washed with a small amount of EtOH, and then with ethyl ether, air-dried. Yield: 92%. Calculated for C18H24N4O5Zn: C, 48.94; H, 5.48; N, 12.68%. Found: C, 48.77, H, 5.54; N, 12.37%. IR (KBr, cm-1): v OH, vNH, 3420 (s, br); v =C-H, 3208 (s); v CH3, 2918 (w); v as(CO2 -), 1617 (vs); v s(CO2 -), 1388 (s).

elements.content: Freshly prepared Cu(OH)2 (1 mmol), l-Hpala (or d-) (2 mmol) and 8 mL of water were stirred at room temperature for 72 h. A dark blue clear solution was obtained, to which Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (1 mmol) was added. The solution was stirred for another 24 h, and then transferred into a test tube. 8 mL of EtOH + H2O (v/v = 1:1) was added as the middle layer carefully. 4,4′-Bipyridyl (bpy, 1 mmol) dissolved in 8 mL of EtOH was layered on the top carefully. Several weeks later, dark blue block crystals appearing on the bottom were collected by filtration, washed with EtOH, and air-dried. Yield: 19% (based on bpy). Calculated for C48H66Cu3N14O28: C, 39.01; H, 4.50; N, 13.27%. Found: C, 38.29, H, 4.52; N, 13.32%. IR (KBr, cm−1): v OH, 3434 (s, br); v =C−H, 3204 (m), 3096 (m); v CH3, 2936 (w); v as(CO2 −), 1614 (vs); v s(CO2 −), 1385 (vs).

Synthesis of [Cu1.5(spp)(bpy)1.5(H2O)2(NO3)](NO3)⋅4H2O (5)

Freshly prepared Cu(OH)2 (1 mmol), l-Hpala (or d-) (2 mmol) and 8 mL of water were stirred at room temperature for 72 h. A dark blue clear solution was obtained, to which Cu(NO3)2⋅3H2O (1 mmol) was added. The solution was stirred for another 24 h, and then transferred into a test tube. 8 mL of EtOH + H2O (v/v = 1:1) was added as the middle layer carefully. 4,4'-Bipyridyl (bpy, 1 mmol) dissolved in 8 mL of EtOH was layered on the top carefully. Several weeks later, dark blue block crystals appearing on the bottom were collected by filtration, washed with EtOH, and air-dried. Yield: 19% (based on bpy). Calculated for C48H66Cu3N14O28: C, 39.01; H, 4.50; N, 13.27%. Found: C, 38.29, H, 4.52; N, 13.32%. IR (KBr, cm-1): v OH, 3434 (s, br); v =C-H, 3204 (m), 3096 (m); v CH3, 2936 (w); v as(CO2 -), 1614 (vs); v s(CO2 -), 1385 (vs).

elements.content: Crystal structure determinations of compounds 1, 4, and 5 were performed on a Rigaku Mercury CCD diffractometer equipped with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at room temperature. The CrytalClear software was used for data reduction and empirical absorption correction. The diffraction data of 2 and 3 were collected on a Siemens SMART 1K CCD diffractometer equipped with Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at room temperature. Data reduction and unit-cell refinement were performed with Smart-CCD software. The structures of compounds 1−5 were solved by direct methods and successive Fourier difference syntheses, and refined by the full-matrix least-squares on F2 (SHELXTL version 5.1). All non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic thermal parameters. Hydrogen atoms bonded to carbon and nitrogen atoms were assigned to theoretical positions with isotropic thermal parameters fixed at 1.2 times that of the attached atoms. Water hydrogen atoms were located at calculated positions by the PLATON program and refined in the riding mode with U iso(H) = 1.5U eq(O). Details of the crystal parameters, data collection, and refinement are summarized in Table . Selected bond lengths and bond angles are listed in Table S1 in . Hydrogen bond geometric parameters are listed in .

As shown in Figure , compounds 1 and 2 are one pair of enantiomers. Their structures were characterized by X-ray crystallography, circular dichroism (CD), elemental analysis (EA), and 1H NMR and IR spectroscopy. They have the same crystal structures except that the chirality on C(2)* is opposite. Therefore, we take 1 as a representative to describe their structures. X-ray single crystal diffraction analysis revealed that the asymmetric unit of 1 consists of one zwitterionic N-(2-pyridylmethyl)-l-alanine molecule and no lattice water molecules were found, coinciding perfectly with the results of EA, while different from the results reported in the literature (l-Hpala·1.25H2O). The almost equal bond lengths of C(1)−O(1) (1.2523(17) Ǻ) and C(1)−O(2) (1.2417(17) Ǻ) indicate the deprotonation of the carboxylic group and the delocalization of the CO bond, in accordance with the IR spectrum. The imino-group N(1) is double protonated to form two intermolecular hydrogen bonds with two O atoms from two neighboring l-Hpala molecules. Thus, the l-Hpala molecule is extended by two strong charge-assisted +N−H···O− hydrogen bonds along the crystallographic a-axis [N(1)−H(1B)...O(1) (x − 1, y, z), N(1)···O(1) = 2.7190(14) Ǻ] and b-axis [N(1)−H(1A)···O(2) (1 − x, 1/2 + y, 1/2 − z), N(1)···O(2) = 2.7817(14) Ǻ] into a 2D undulate supramolecular structure as exhibited in Figure . The shortest separation between two parallel adjacent pyridine rings is 5.335 Ǻ (based on the centers of pyridine rings), indicating no π−π stacking interaction between them. Compound 1 crystallizes in the chiral P212121 space group (No. 19). As the synthesis and crystallization process do not change the chirality on C(2), the absolute configuration of Hpala is predetermined to be the l-form. Because of the lack of atoms heavier than Si in the l-Hpala molecule, the absolute structure of the crystal cannot be determined by the anomalous dispersion effects in diffraction measurements on the crystal.

Results and Discussion

Crystal Structures of (l-Hpala) (1) and (d-Hpala) (2)

As shown in Figure , compounds 1 and 2 are one pair of enantiomers. Their structures were characterized by X-ray crystallography, circular dichroism (CD), elemental analysis (EA), and 1H NMR and IR spectroscopy. They have the same crystal structures except that the chirality on C(2)* is opposite. Therefore, we take 1 as a representative to describe their structures. X-ray single crystal diffraction analysis revealed that the asymmetric unit of 1 consists of one zwitterionic N-(2-pyridylmethyl)-l-alanine molecule and no lattice water molecules were found, coinciding perfectly with the results of EA, while different from the results reported in the literature (l-Hpala⋅1.25H2O). The almost equal bond lengths of C(1)-O(1) (1.2523(17) Ǻ) and C(1)-O(2) (1.2417(17) Ǻ) indicate the deprotonation of the carboxylic group and the delocalization of the CO bond, in accordance with the IR spectrum. The imino-group N(1) is double protonated to form two intermolecular hydrogen bonds with two O atoms from two neighboring l-Hpala molecules. Thus, the l-Hpala molecule is extended by two strong charge-assisted +N-H⋅⋅⋅O- hydrogen bonds along the crystallographic a-axis [N(1)-H(1B)...O(1) (x - 1, y, z), N(1)⋅⋅⋅O(1) = 2.7190(14) Ǻ] and b-axis [N(1)-H(1A)⋅⋅⋅O(2) (1 - x, 1/2 + y, 1/2 - z), N(1)⋅⋅⋅O(2) = 2.7817(14) Ǻ] into a 2D undulate supramolecular structure as exhibited in Figure . The shortest separation between two parallel adjacent pyridine rings is 5.335 Ǻ (based on the centers of pyridine rings), indicating no π-π stacking interaction between them. Compound 1 crystallizes in the chiral P212121 space group (No. 19). As the synthesis and crystallization process do not change the chirality on C(2), the absolute configuration of Hpala is predetermined to be the l-form. Because of the lack of atoms heavier than Si in the l-Hpala molecule, the absolute structure of the crystal cannot be determined by the anomalous dispersion effects in diffraction measurements on the crystal.

elements.content: Similar to those of 1 and 2, 3 and 4 are also one pair of enantiomers (Figure ). X-ray single crystal diffraction, CD, EA, and IR confirm that they have the same structures except the opposite chiralities on C(2)*, N(1)*, and Zn(II)*. Take 3 as an example: it is a discrete neutral mononuclear complex that consists of one Zn(II) ion, two symmetry-related l-pala− anions, and one lattice water molecule. It crystallizes in the chiral C2221 space group (No. 20) with a flack factor of 0.08(3) (Table ), indicating the right absolute structure. Each l-pala− anion acts as a tridentate ligand through its monodentate carboxylate group, pyridyl and imino- N atoms to coordinate to one Zn center in a fac-manner featuring two types of five-membered rings (ZnC2N2 and ZnC2NO rings). The coordination sphere of the metal center are occupied by two carboxylate O atoms, two imino- N atoms and two pyridyl N atoms from two l-pala− ligands with a distorted octahedron coordination geometry. The Zn−O(1), Zn−N(1), Zn−N(2) distances are 2.064(3), 2.171(4), 2.215(4) Ǻ, respectively. Two pyridyl groups lie in the apical position, while two imino- N atoms and two carboxylate O atoms occupy the equatorial positions in a cis-form. It is different from the trans-form observed in [Zn(pgly)2]·2H2O and [Cu(pgly)2]·2H2O [Hpgly = N-(2-pyridylmethyl)-glycine], which crystallized in the centrosymmetric P21/c space group (No. 14). The Hpgly ligand is achiral and consequently adopted the higher symmetric trans-form with an inversion center lying in the metal center when it chelates to octahedral Cu(II) or Zn(II) in a 2:1 ratio. From the difference of coordination mode between the chiral Hpala and achiral Hpgly, we can see that the chirality transfer from ligand to complex is efficient. The discrete mononulear complex is extended by charge-assisted +N−H···O− hydrogen bonds [N(1)−H(1)···O(1), N(1)···O(1) = 2.943(5) Ǻ] along the crystallographic a-axis into a 1D supramolecular chain, which is further extended by hydrogen bonding with lattice water molecules [O(3)−H(3)···O(2), O(3)···O(2) = 2.896(5) Ǻ] along the c-axis into a 2D undulate supramolecular layer as depicted in Figure . The shortest separation between two parallel adjacent pyridine rings is 5.606 Ǻ (based on the centers of pyridine rings), indicative of no π−π stacking interaction between them.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structures of [Zn(l-pala)2]⋅H2O (3) and [Zn(d-pala)2]⋅H2O (4)

Similar to those of 1 and 2, 3 and 4 are also one pair of enantiomers (Figure ). X-ray single crystal diffraction, CD, EA, and IR confirm that they have the same structures except the opposite chiralities on C(2)*, N(1)*, and Zn(II)*. Take 3 as an example: it is a discrete neutral mononuclear complex that consists of one Zn(II) ion, two symmetry-related l-pala- anions, and one lattice water molecule. It crystallizes in the chiral C2221 space group (No. 20) with a flack factor of 0.08(3) (Table ), indicating the right absolute structure. Each l-pala- anion acts as a tridentate ligand through its monodentate carboxylate group, pyridyl and imino- N atoms to coordinate to one Zn center in a fac-manner featuring two types of five-membered rings (ZnC2N2 and ZnC2NO rings). The coordination sphere of the metal center are occupied by two carboxylate O atoms, two imino- N atoms and two pyridyl N atoms from two l-pala- ligands with a distorted octahedron coordination geometry. The Zn-O(1), Zn-N(1), Zn-N(2) distances are 2.064(3), 2.171(4), 2.215(4) Ǻ, respectively. Two pyridyl groups lie in the apical position, while two imino- N atoms and two carboxylate O atoms occupy the equatorial positions in a cis-form. It is different from the trans-form observed in [Zn(pgly)2]⋅2H2O and [Cu(pgly)2]⋅2H2O [Hpgly = N-(2-pyridylmethyl)-glycine], which crystallized in the centrosymmetric P21/c space group (No. 14). The Hpgly ligand is achiral and consequently adopted the higher symmetric trans-form with an inversion center lying in the metal center when it chelates to octahedral Cu(II) or Zn(II) in a 2:1 ratio. From the difference of coordination mode between the chiral Hpala and achiral Hpgly, we can see that the chirality transfer from ligand to complex is efficient. The discrete mononulear complex is extended by charge-assisted +N-H⋅⋅⋅O- hydrogen bonds [N(1)-H(1)⋅⋅⋅O(1), N(1)⋅⋅⋅O(1) = 2.943(5) Ǻ] along the crystallographic a-axis into a 1D supramolecular chain, which is further extended by hydrogen bonding with lattice water molecules [O(3)-H(3)⋅⋅⋅O(2), O(3)⋅⋅⋅O(2) = 2.896(5) Ǻ] along the c-axis into a 2D undulate supramolecular layer as depicted in Figure . The shortest separation between two parallel adjacent pyridine rings is 5.606 Ǻ (based on the centers of pyridine rings), indicative of no π-π stacking interaction between them.

elements.content: Interestingly, the Hpala ligand contains a cryptochiral N(1) atom. The deprotonation of N(1) and its following coordination to the Zn(II) center result in chiralities on N(1) and Zn(II) in compounds 3 and 4. The C(2), N(1) atoms and Zn(II) ion in 3 have the S C-R N-ΛZn configuration, while those in 4 have the opposite R C-S N-ΔZn configuration (Figures S1−S2 in ), suggesting that 3 and 4 are mirror images of one another. The chirality on C(2) is predetermined and unchangeable, while those on N(1) and Zn(II) are cryptical and variable. It is evident that the chiralities on N(1) and Zn(II) are dependent on that of C(2), namely, the assembly and crystallization process are stereoselective.

elements.content: Compound 5 was synthesized by slow diffusion of 4,4′-bpy ethanol solution into Cu2+ + pala− + NO3 − (1:1:1) water solution. It is noteworthy that the assembly process involves the in situ oxidation of pala− into a Schiff base N-(2-pyridylmethyl)-pyruvic acid (spp−) (Scheme ). X-ray single crystal diffraction analysis reveals that 5 crystallizes in the centrosymmetric C2/c space group (No. 15), the correctness of which is confirmed by the PLATON program. It is also consistent with the fact that 5 is CD silent. In the crystal structure of 5, the C(2)−N(1) bond length is 1.362(7) Ǻ, significantly shorter than the value 1.494 Ǻ in the free ligand and 1.485 Ǻ and 1.512 Ǻ in the documented examples of the l-Hpala ligand with similar coordination modes, but very close to that of delocalized CN in a conjugated system such as pyridyl group. On the other hand, C(3) lies in the plane generated by Cu(1)N(1)C(2)C(1)O(1) with a negligible deviation of 0.14 Ǻ, and the C(3)−C(2) bond length is 1.437(7) Ǻ, shorter than that of the C(sp3)-C(sp3) (ca. 1.520 Ǻ) in the free ligand Hpala but similar to those with comparable C(sp3)-C(sp2) (ca. 1.433 Ǻ) in some mythacrylic acid compounds. The above evidence suggests that the bond between C(2) and N(1) is a double bond and conjugated with the carboxylate group. In other words, the reduced Schiff base ligand Hpala was oxidized to a Schiff base (Hspp) in the assembly process. It is very similar to the coordination between some amino acid ligands and transition metals, where the transition metals may act as catalysts in the oxidation reaction. However, the effect of 4,4′-bpy and some other unexpectable factors also cannot be excluded, and the mechanism of these oxidation is yet to be further explored. Interestingly, the oxidation leads to the dechirality on C(2) and N(1) of the pala− ligand, and to some extent, accounting for the crystallization of 5 in the centrosymmetric C2/c space group.

elements.content: The asymmetric unit of 5 consists of a cationic [Cu1.5(spp)(bpy)1.5(H2O)2(NO3)]+, one counterionic NO3 −, and four lattice water molecules (Figure ). Cu(1) has a distorted [CuN3O3] octahedral coordination geometry. The equatorial plane is taken up by two N atoms and one O atom from the tridentate spp− ligand and one N atom from bpy ligand. The average Cu−N bond length is about 1.981 Ǻ, and the Cu(1)−O(1) distance is 1.960(3) Ǻ. The remaining two coordination sites at the apical positions are taken up by one H2O molecule and one NO3 − O atom, and both of them are terminal ligands. The Cu−O distances are 2.516(4) and 2.594(5) Ǻ, respectively, significantly longer than those on the equatorial plane. This axial elongation could be attributed to the strong Jahn−Teller effect of Cu(II) with a d9 electronic state. Different from Cu(1), Cu(2) is a half-occupied atom in the asymmetric unit. It is also six-coordinated in a distorted [CuN4O2] octahedron geometry. Four pyridyl groups from bpy ligands occupy the equatorial positions with an average Cu−N distance of about 2.038 Ǻ, while the axial positions are terminated by two symmetry-related H2O molecules. The Cu−O bond length is 2.489(4) Ǻ, obviously longer than the four equatorial Cu−N bond lengths due to the Jahn−Teller effect. So the coordination geometry of Cu(2) is also an elongated octahedron. The bond dimensions involving Cu are normal () and comparable to the values in some other Cu(II) complexes. Cu(2) is connected by four bpy ligands on the crystallographic ab plane, while terminated by two equivalents of [Cu(spp)(H2O)(NO3)] along the a-axis. The two pyridyl groups within the bpy ligand linking Cu(1) and Cu(2) are almost coplanar with a dihedral angle of about 6.17°, while that linking Cu(2) and its symmetrical equivalent is noncoplanar with a dihedral angle of about 47.08°. As depicted in Figure , the structure of 5 features an antenna-shaped 1D Cu(II) coordination polymer extending along the crystallographic b-axis. The positive “antenna” [Cu1.5(spp)(bpy)1.5(H2O)2(NO3)] n n+ is charge balanced by one equivalent of NO3 − counterions. As shown in Figure , neighboring “antennas” are mutually geared by interantenna hydrogen bonds to form a 2D supramolecular Cu-containing sheet on the crystallographic ab plane. The Cu-containing sheet is stabilized not only by hydrogen bonds but also by π−π stacking interactions between pyridine rings from adjacent spp− ligands and bpy ligands. The shortest separation between two adjacent pyridine rings is 3.639 Ǻ (based on the centers of pyridine rings as shown in Figure ) with a dihedral angle of 12.52°, indicative of π−π stacking interaction between them.

elements.content: Interestingly, hydrogen-bonding associations between two coordinated water molecules, four lattice water molecules, nitrates and carboxylate O atoms lead to the formation of an aesthetically beautiful supramolecular layer lying between every two adjacent Cu-sheets. The supramolecular layer consists of five types of fused rings: Ra (6-membered), Rb (8-membered), Rc (11-membered), Rd (12-membered), and Re (16-membered) (detailed hydrogen bonding of five types of rings are shown in Figure S2 in ). All the rings lie in crystallographic inversion centers except Rc. Ra is composed of a sequence of hydrogen bonds [O(1w)-O(3w)-O(5)-O(1w)-O(3w)-O(5)-] with an inversion center that lies in the middle. Rb consists of two centrosymmetry-related sequences [O(2w)-O(5w)-O(6w)-O(6)-]. Rc is an asymmetric ring consisting of a sequence of hydrogen bonds [O(2)-O(2w)-O(6)N(8)O(7)-O(4w)-O(3)N(7)O(5)-O(3w)-O(1w)-). Rd and Re are composed of two centrosymmetric units [O(4w)-O(5w)-O(6w)-O(6)N(8)O(7)-] and [O(2)-O(1w)-O(5)N(7)O(3)-O(4w)-O(5w)-O(2w)-], respectively. The five types of rings arrange fusedly with each other, generating an aesthetically beautiful supramolecular layer (Figure ). Within the layer, the O···O distances range from 2.759(11) Ǻ to 3.023(10) Ǻ with an average distance of about 2.861 Ǻ (Table S2 in ). The overall structure of 5 is a three-dimensional (3D) supramolecular network based on the alternate ...ABAB... stacking of two kinds of supramolecular layers, where A is the Cu-containing sheet and B represents the hydrogen-bonded 2D supramolecular layer (Figure ). The two layers are connected with each other not only by interlayer hydrogen bonds but also by coordination bonds [Cu(1)−O(4), Cu(1)−O(3w), and Cu(2)−O(6w)].

elements.content: Compounds 1 and 2, 3 and 4 have very similar IR spectra, so we take 1, 3, and 5 as representatives to illustrate their IR spectra (Figure S4−S6 in ). The IR spectrum of 1 showed completely different absorption bands from that reported in the literature, and we think that it was caused by the presence of the lattice water molecules which might originate from an impurity of H2O in the MeOH solvent used in the literature. The broad absorption band in the region 2250−2700 cm−1 is characteristic of the asymmetric and symmetric stretching vibration of the NH2 + group. The strong absorption band at 1578 cm−1 is attributed to the asymmetric stretching vibration of the CO2 − group, which exhibits a significant red-shift as compared to that of the protonated carboxylate group monomer (1760 cm−1) and 1717 cm−1 reported in the literature, indicating the zwitterionic state of Hpala and the delocalization of the CO double bond. Noticing the almost equal bond lengths of the C(1)−O(1) and C(1)−O(2) (), the result is consistent with the single crystal X-ray analysis. The absorption band at 1397 cm−1 is due to the symmetric stretching vibration of the CO2 − group. The IR spectrum of 3 displays the typical broad absorption band of the stretching vibration of hydrogen bonded O−H and N−H centered at 3420 cm−1. The bands at 1617 cm−1 and 1388 cm−1 are attributed to the asymmetric and symmetric stretching vibration of the monodentate carboxylate group of the l-pala− ligand, respectively. In the IR spectrum of 5, the strong band at 1614 cm−1 can be attributed to the stretching vibration of the monodentate carboxylate group or the CN bond of the spp− ligand. The band at 1385 cm−1 is the symmetric stretching vibration of the CO2 − group. The broad band centered at 3434 cm−1 is the stretching vibration of hydrogen bonded O−H of coordinated and lattice water molecules.
elements.clean_text:
FT-IR Spectra and Thermogravimetric Analysis

Compounds 1 and 2, 3 and 4 have very similar IR spectra, so we take 1, 3, and 5 as representatives to illustrate their IR spectra (Figure S4-S6 in ). The IR spectrum of 1 showed completely different absorption bands from that reported in the literature, and we think that it was caused by the presence of the lattice water molecules which might originate from an impurity of H2O in the MeOH solvent used in the literature. The broad absorption band in the region 2250-2700 cm-1 is characteristic of the asymmetric and symmetric stretching vibration of the NH2 + group. The strong absorption band at 1578 cm-1 is attributed to the asymmetric stretching vibration of the CO2 - group, which exhibits a significant red-shift as compared to that of the protonated carboxylate group monomer (1760 cm-1) and 1717 cm-1 reported in the literature, indicating the zwitterionic state of Hpala and the delocalization of the CO double bond. Noticing the almost equal bond lengths of the C(1)-O(1) and C(1)-O(2) (), the result is consistent with the single crystal X-ray analysis. The absorption band at 1397 cm-1 is due to the symmetric stretching vibration of the CO2 - group. The IR spectrum of 3 displays the typical broad absorption band of the stretching vibration of hydrogen bonded O-H and N-H centered at 3420 cm-1. The bands at 1617 cm-1 and 1388 cm-1 are attributed to the asymmetric and symmetric stretching vibration of the monodentate carboxylate group of the l-pala- ligand, respectively. In the IR spectrum of 5, the strong band at 1614 cm-1 can be attributed to the stretching vibration of the monodentate carboxylate group or the CN bond of the spp- ligand. The band at 1385 cm-1 is the symmetric stretching vibration of the CO2 - group. The broad band centered at 3434 cm-1 is the stretching vibration of hydrogen bonded O-H of coordinated and lattice water molecules.

elements.content: The thermal stability of compounds 1, 3, and 5 were examined by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) in an N2 atmosphere (30−500 °C for 1 and 30−900 °C for 3 and 5, Figure S7 in ). The TGA curve of 1 exhibits a stable plateau in the temperature range of 40−220 °C, and then a sharp drop in weight is observed after 220 °C, indicating the complete decomposition of the ligand. The TGA curve of 3 displays two main steps of weight losses. The weight loss from 70 to 130 °C is observed to be 3.9%, corresponding to the release of the lattice water molecule (theoretical value 4.0%). The second step covers a temperature range of 130−250 °C, during which the curve shows a plateau and no weight loss happens. Upon further heating, a sharp drop in weight is observed in the temperature range of 250−400 °C, suggesting the decomposition of the bulky ligand. Then the residues continue to lose weight slowly above 400 °C. The total weight losses in the range of 30−900 °C is about 81.4%, very close to the theoretical value 81.6%, and the final residue is ZnO. The TGA curve of 5 also displays two main steps of weight losses. The weight loss from 35 to 80 °C is about 10.0%, corresponding to the loss of four uncoordinated lattice water molecules (theoretical value 9.75%). Then it shows a relatively stable plateau in the temperature range 80−150 °C. The further loss of two coordinated water molecules occurred from 150 to 190 °C, among which the weight loss is about 4.9% (theoretical value 4.88%). Upon further heating, a sharp drop in weight (70.5%) is observed in the temperature range of 190−300 °C, representing the combustion of the ligands. Then it continues to decompose slowly above this temperature and the final residue is mainly CuO. The total weight loss in the range of 30−900 °C is about 81.7%, slightly smaller than the theoretical value 83.7%.

elements.content: The UV absorption and solid-state circular dichroism (CD) spectra of compounds 1−4 were measured by using pressed KCl pellets in the range of 200−400 nm at room temperature (Figure and ). The UV absorption bands of the free ligand (1) and its Zn complex (3) occurred at 255 nm and 262 nm, respectively (), both of which were originated from π−π* transition of the chromogenic pyridyl group. However, it red-shifted 7 nm after coordination to the Zn(II) ion. In the CD spectra (Figure ), 1 and 2 exhibit opposite Cotton effects at the same wavelengths (a strong signal at 271 nm, and two weak signals at 217 nm and 206 nm) with equivalent intensities, indicating that they are a pair of enantiomers. Similarly, the spectra patterns of 3 and 4 are inverted from each other with a strong band at 259 nm and a medium band at 217 nm. By comparison with the free ligands (1 and 2), the CD signals of the Zn complexes (3 and 4) in the range of 250−280 nm blue-shifted 12 nm (271 → 259 nm), while the Cotton effects between 200 and 230 nm were significantly different. It means that the two new chiral centers [N(2) and Zn(II)] that originated from the stereoselective assembly of the chiral ligand with Zn(II) may exhibit a chiral vicinal effects on the pyridyl and carbonyl chromophores, thus accounting for the difference between their CD spectra. It also means that the chirality transition from ligand to complex and crystal is highly efficient.
elements.clean_text:
UV Absorption, Chiroptical, and Photoluminescence Properties

The UV absorption and solid-state circular dichroism (CD) spectra of compounds 1-4 were measured by using pressed KCl pellets in the range of 200-400 nm at room temperature (Figure  and ). The UV absorption bands of the free ligand (1) and its Zn complex (3) occurred at 255 nm and 262 nm, respectively (), both of which were originated from π-π* transition of the chromogenic pyridyl group. However, it red-shifted 7 nm after coordination to the Zn(II) ion. In the CD spectra (Figure ), 1 and 2 exhibit opposite Cotton effects at the same wavelengths (a strong signal at 271 nm, and two weak signals at 217 nm and 206 nm) with equivalent intensities, indicating that they are a pair of enantiomers. Similarly, the spectra patterns of 3 and 4 are inverted from each other with a strong band at 259 nm and a medium band at 217 nm. By comparison with the free ligands (1 and 2), the CD signals of the Zn complexes (3 and 4) in the range of 250-280 nm blue-shifted 12 nm (271 → 259 nm), while the Cotton effects between 200 and 230 nm were significantly different. It means that the two new chiral centers [N(2) and Zn(II)] that originated from the stereoselective assembly of the chiral ligand with Zn(II) may exhibit a chiral vicinal effects on the pyridyl and carbonyl chromophores, thus accounting for the difference between their CD spectra. It also means that the chirality transition from ligand to complex and crystal is highly efficient.

elements.content: In conclusion, five supramolecular compounds based on Hpala ligands and its in situ oxidized derivative Hspp ligand have been synthesized and characterized. X-ray single crystal diffraction analysis and CD spectra revealed that compounds 1−4 were 2D homochiral supramolecules extended by intermolecular hydrogen bonds. Compounds 1 and 2, 3 and 4 are one pair of enantiomers, respectively. Compound 5 features a mutually geared antenna-shaped Cu-containing sheet and an aesthetically pleasing supramolecular layer consisting of five types of supramolecular rings. The two kinds of layers interconnect with each other by hydrogen bonds and coordination bonds in the alternate ...ABAB... stacking mode into a 3D supramolecular network. The synthesis of 5 involves the in situ oxidation of enantiopure Hpala into achiral Hspp, and consequently the crystallization of 5 in a centrosymmetric space group. Therefore, the usage of chiral ligand is an efficient way to obtain homochiral supramolecular structures, and hydrogen bonds involving lattice water molecules play a very important role in extending the dimensionality of supramolecules.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In conclusion, five supramolecular compounds based on Hpala ligands and its in situ oxidized derivative Hspp ligand have been synthesized and characterized. X-ray single crystal diffraction analysis and CD spectra revealed that compounds 1-4 were 2D homochiral supramolecules extended by intermolecular hydrogen bonds. Compounds 1 and 2, 3 and 4 are one pair of enantiomers, respectively. Compound 5 features a mutually geared antenna-shaped Cu-containing sheet and an aesthetically pleasing supramolecular layer consisting of five types of supramolecular rings. The two kinds of layers interconnect with each other by hydrogen bonds and coordination bonds in the alternate ...ABAB... stacking mode into a 3D supramolecular network. The synthesis of 5 involves the in situ oxidation of enantiopure Hpala into achiral Hspp, and consequently the crystallization of 5 in a centrosymmetric space group. Therefore, the usage of chiral ligand is an efficient way to obtain homochiral supramolecular structures, and hydrogen bonds involving lattice water molecules play a very important role in extending the dimensionality of supramolecules.

cln_elements.content:
As described in the literature, l-Hpala (or d-Hpala) was synthesized by the condensation reaction of 2-pyridinecarboxaldehyde with alanine (l- for 1 and d- for 2) and subsequent reduction by NaBH4. X-ray quality single crystals and analytically pure samples were obtained by recrystallization in MeOH. Calculated for C9H12N2O2: C, 59.99; H, 6.71; N, 15.55%. Found: C, 59.58, H, 6.58; N, 15.17%. 1H NMR in D2O (ppm), 1.541 (3H, d), 3.781 (1H, q), 4.377 (2H, s), 7.475 (1H, t), 7.522 (1H, d), 7.914 (1H, t), 8.586 (1H, d). IR (KBr, cm−1): v =C−H, 3028 (m); v CH3, 2979 (m); v CH2, 2841 (m); v NH2 +, 2250−2700 (m, br); v as(CO2 −),1578 (vs); v s(CO2 −), 1397 (vs). [α]20 D = +5.2° for l-Hpala (dextrorotatory); [α]20 D = −5.2° for d-Hpala (levorotatory).

Syntheses of [Zn(<sc>l</sc>-pala)<sub>2</sub>]·H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>3</bold>) and [Zn(<sc>d</sc>-pala)<sub>2</sub>]·H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>4</bold>)

Zn(CH3CO2)2·2H2O (1 mmol) and Hpala (l- for 3 and d- for 4) (2 mmol) were dissolved in MeOH (10 mL) and stirred for 30 min. The clear solution thus formed was left undisturbed for slow evaporation. Colorless rodlike crystals were harvested several days later, washed with a small amount of EtOH, and then with ethyl ether, air-dried. Yield: 92%. Calculated for C18H24N4O5Zn: C, 48.94; H, 5.48; N, 12.68%. Found: C, 48.77, H, 5.54; N, 12.37%. IR (KBr, cm−1): v OH, vNH, 3420 (s, br); v =C−H, 3208 (s); v CH3, 2918 (w); v as(CO2 −), 1617 (vs); v s(CO2 −), 1388 (s).

Synthesis of [Cu<sub>1.5</sub>(spp)(bpy)<sub>1.5</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>2</sub>(NO<sub>3</sub>)](NO<sub>3</sub>)·4H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>5</bold>)

Freshly prepared Cu(OH)2 (1 mmol), l-Hpala (or d-) (2 mmol) and 8 mL of water were stirred at room temperature for 72 h. A dark blue clear solution was obtained, to which Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (1 mmol) was added. The solution was stirred for another 24 h, and then transferred into a test tube. 8 mL of EtOH + H2O (v/v = 1:1) was added as the middle layer carefully. 4,4′-Bipyridyl (bpy, 1 mmol) dissolved in 8 mL of EtOH was layered on the top carefully. Several weeks later, dark blue block crystals appearing on the bottom were collected by filtration, washed with EtOH, and air-dried. Yield: 19% (based on bpy). Calculated for C48H66Cu3N14O28: C, 39.01; H, 4.50; N, 13.27%. Found: C, 38.29, H, 4.52; N, 13.32%. IR (KBr, cm−1): v OH, 3434 (s, br); v =C−H, 3204 (m), 3096 (m); v CH3, 2936 (w); v as(CO2 −), 1614 (vs); v s(CO2 −), 1385 (vs).

cln_elements.content:
The thermal stability of compounds 1, 3, and 5 were examined by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) in an N2 atmosphere (30−500 °C for 1 and 30−900 °C for 3 and 5, Figure S7 in ). The TGA curve of 1 exhibits a stable plateau in the temperature range of 40−220 °C, and then a sharp drop in weight is observed after 220 °C, indicating the complete decomposition of the ligand. The TGA curve of 3 displays two main steps of weight losses. The weight loss from 70 to 130 °C is observed to be 3.9%, corresponding to the release of the lattice water molecule (theoretical value 4.0%). The second step covers a temperature range of 130−250 °C, during which the curve shows a plateau and no weight loss happens. Upon further heating, a sharp drop in weight is observed in the temperature range of 250−400 °C, suggesting the decomposition of the bulky ligand. Then the residues continue to lose weight slowly above 400 °C. The total weight losses in the range of 30−900 °C is about 81.4%, very close to the theoretical value 81.6%, and the final residue is ZnO. The TGA curve of 5 also displays two main steps of weight losses. The weight loss from 35 to 80 °C is about 10.0%, corresponding to the loss of four uncoordinated lattice water molecules (theoretical value 9.75%). Then it shows a relatively stable plateau in the temperature range 80−150 °C. The further loss of two coordinated water molecules occurred from 150 to 190 °C, among which the weight loss is about 4.9% (theoretical value 4.88%). Upon further heating, a sharp drop in weight (70.5%) is observed in the temperature range of 190−300 °C, representing the combustion of the ligands. Then it continues to decompose slowly above this temperature and the final residue is mainly CuO. The total weight loss in the range of 30−900 °C is about 81.7%, slightly smaller than the theoretical value 83.7%.

In addition, the photoluminescence properties of the free ligand (1) and its Zn(II) complex (3) were examined in the solid-state at room temperature. Upon excitation at 340 nm, compounds 1 and 3 exhibited broad emission bands centered at 417 nm and 420 nm, respectively (Figure ). Both of the emissions can be assigned to ligand-to-ligand charge transfer (LLCT).
